div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. div.head: THE MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
div.p: An important announcement appears in this morning’s telegrams in regard to the Morocco Conference, which, it is to be hoped, will have a reassuring effect on Europe. The Cologne Gazette, which has often been employed to convey important information by the Imperial Government, ridicules the idea of war resulting should the Conference prove abortive, and declares that the status quo will be maintained even if all the debates at Algeciras end in a fiasco. A Renter« telegram from Berlin declares that the article is inspired, and if so, its publica-tion it evidently due to a desire of the Berlin Government to remove the existing very general distrust of German diplomacy. It may be, of course, that there is no ground for pessimism, and that both Count Tattenbach and Herr von Radowitz have received instructions to be oonciliatory ; bat the history of the Moroccan dispute so far does not encourage sanguine anticipations. Until it is known exactly what claims Germany advances, there can be no certainty that the Conference will not fail. One thing, however, is assured, Great Britain is in thorough agreement with the French claims, and throughout the Conference it will be the duty of our representative to support M. Revoil; in the unhappy event of an arrangement not being arrived at, the British Government will still be ready to assist France in whatever way is needful to secure justice. This, we take it is generally understood in Europe and it is now realised that any hopes that have been built on the present change of Administration at home, and a consequent vacillation on of policy, are unfounded. Up to now there has been much talk of conciliation and of the entirely pacific inten-tions of Germany, such amiable assurances having bean freely provided by the German Press. Unfortunately, however, there is nothing to show that the German representatives at the Conference have received instructions of a really conciliatory nature. On the contrary, there has hitherto been no abatement in the insistence of the German inspired Press on the necessity of internationalising' the Moroccan police, excepting that on the Algerian frontier.” That proposal will be resisted by Prance and the Powers which will act with her. These Powers, as we know, are England, Russia, Italy, and, in all probability. 8pain and the United States. Against such a combination Germany will be powerless, and she will have either to submit or to upset the card table by a gesture of impatience which might have the most serious consequences to the world's peace. It would appear, however, from the announcement which the Berlin Government has made through the Cologne Gazette that Germany has decided to submit.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p:
TIME CONCENTRATION MARCH. Owing to the Bairam Holidays, the troops of the Egyptian Army will not be able to join in a field day during the ensuing week. In place of the usual weekly field day the troops of the Army of Occupation will be exercised t> morrow in a Time Concentration March, under the following scheme Abbassia.—M.I., M.M.P., 1st Bn. K.R.R. Corps, with 1 maohiue gun, will parade under orders of the Commandant so as to move off at 8 a.m. They will march t j the Abattoir from which point they will be lei to the Citadel (Inner Square opposite the Officers Mess), by an Intelligence Officer detailed by the General Officer Commanding. The M.M.P. will atop in the Outer Square Kaar-e.-Nil.— 2nd Co, R R 2nd Bn. Royal Instilling Fusiliers, with 8 machine guns, will parade under orders of the Commandant so as to move off at 9 a m., and will be led to the Inner Square. Citadel, as above Citadel.—R G A with 2 15-pr. guns 2nd Bn. Royal Berk-*. Regt., will parade under orders from the Commandant in the Outer Square, Citadel, opposite the Guard Room, at 10 a.m. After the troops have met at the rendezvous they will form into three columns as follows: - let Column (Outer 8quare) to march off at 10 20 am. - R G. A., 2nd Bo Royal Berkshire Regiment under the command of Major R. Percy-Smith. R.G.A., will be led to the second place of rendezvous as above. 2nd Column (Officer's Me Square) to march off at 10.35 a.m.—M.l. 1st Bn , KRR Corps UNDER THE COMMAND OF LT COL CJ MARKAM 1st Bn. KRR Corps, will be led to the 2nd place of rendezvous as above.
The object of the exercise is to concentrate definite place at a definite time.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Paniau idlicea of the Anglo-Egyptian | Hank have been removed to 29 Rue Taitboot. A- S C * Lieut. Napier, A. S. C., ha* been appointed to the Army Service Corps at Cairo in place I of Lieut. Bleucowe, who baa proceeded to | Khartoum. Gordon College Mr. George Urqnbart, bridge contractor. Sudan Government Railways, has undertaken the construction of the west wing of Gord in College at Khartoum at the coat of L.R 12,000 Rifle Meeting. The detachment of the A. S. C. at Alexandria have entered a team for the forthcoming title meeting at Cairo. Taking into consideration the excellent shooting this detachment did last year, they ought to make a record for themselves The Bishop's Visit to Egypt, Bishop Byh. Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem and the East arrives at Port Said and proceed to Cairo on Wednesday next. His Lordship will visit Alexandria from February 17-19 and on Sunday the 18th inst., will officiate at 8t. Mark’s, Alexandria, and All Saint’s, Ramleh. Millionaire Dies at Cairo. Thomas J. Emery, the multi-millionaire of Cincinnati, who has died in Cairo, was on his tenth trip to Africa and his fiftieth trip to Europe. Mr. Emery was a patron of the arts, and noted for his philanthropy. He was notably generous in aid of Booker T. Washington's educational work. Renta at Alexandria. An Arabic contempoary publishes an article advocating the dredging and restoration of the port of Damieta as a panacea for the extortionate increases of rents in Alexandria. The argument is that if Dami-tta was restored to its ancient prosperity the surplus population of Alexandria would be drawn thither, thereby decreasing the demaod for houses here.
